content.webTitle: From Pompey to Sunderland: A brief history of troubled takeovers

fields.headline: From Pompey to Sunderland: A brief history of troubled takeovers
fields.bodyText: Funding from overseas businessmen has become the accepted path to salvation for Premier League clubs, yet Portsmouth are the fourth within a short period whose takeover has not worked out, forcing the clubs to seek another buyer West Ham United Bjorgolfur Gudmundsson took over in December 2006 and put around £30m into the club, but his wealth has melted away in Iceland's economic collapse. The club has been effectively repossessed by Straumur, a bank to whom Gudmundsson owed money, which is itself in severe financial difficulties Manchester City Were racking up debts under Thaksin Shinawatra until August 2008, when Pairoj Piempongsant met Sulaiman Al-Fahim. He was representing Sheikh Mansour of Abu Dhabi, who bought the club Sunderland Bought by the Irish Drumaville consortium of businessmen in 2006; their loans reached £16.8m last year, helping Sunderland win promotion. Then they too became victims of the recession, and chairman Niall Quinn secured Dallas investor Ellis Short to take 100% control
